utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: We're in the car, honey. We're going to the hospital for tests.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: We're in the hospital. We're going to the Doctor's office.

utterance.speaker: Andres
utterance.content: Uh, you use it to get food from inside.

utterance.speaker: Andres
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Andres
utterance.content: Uh, no, it's, um… it's, um… You're trying to make me look stupid. You can go to hell! Why don't you kill yourself?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Andres. It's okay.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Here I am. Here, come on. You just need to answer a few more questions. Then we're going home. We'll have lunch, okay?

utterance.speaker: Andres
utterance.content: Okay. I'm sorry. I have Alzheimer's.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: The mood swings come on quickly, but, um… It's under control.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Andres… Oh, my God! Andres…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Early onset familial Alzheimer's. Brazilian descent. Blood chemistry showed high ammonia. Vomiting stopped after the E.R. put him on antiemetics.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Any recent health issues?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Just a sore throat a few weeks ago.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: How advanced is he? Could be hyperalimentation.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Advanced enough, but no IV feedings. The wife shut down a floral company to stay home and feed him every meal he's had in the last four years.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do we owe this case to your guilt at having ignored your own forgetful mommy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: My guilt over my mom is why I put up with my dad. You're taking this case because we're running a phase-two trial on an Alzheimer's drug.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You couldn't round up enough doddering old Guinea pigs. You need us to fix this little piggy?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'd like to sit in. Especially since you're short a team member.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You mean Taub? Got him in here.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He asked for a personal day. His daughter's sick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Isn't that the point of having a spare? I denied his request.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: After I'd already approved it, which you knew because I sent you a memo.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Adams… taped under your chair is an index card. Would you read it, please?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: "Wednesday, 2:43 p.m., a black Pawn will believe he's the black King and attempt to capture the… white head of diagnostics."

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: It's 10:15 on Friday.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Damn it. Look, the point is I saw this coming. Dr. Foreman and I did not always see eye-to-eye. But he never had the power to overrule me. Now that he has the power, he won't be able to resist the temptation to use it. With great power comes great micromanaging. And great vests.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I know you're the better diagnostician. I'm not gonna interfere. I'm only here to help.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Could be transient nitrogen load from a G.I. bleed.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not if the vomiting's persistent.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which we won't know, because the E.R. put him on antiemetics. Take him off.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wait. He's puking his guts out. We'd risk aspiration. I'm just disagreeing, not overruling.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So glad you're on board. Take him off antiemetics, do an upper endoscopy to check for bleeds.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It could be a bladder infection. We'll run a pregnancy test.

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: Oh, I'm not pregnant.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Any type of birth control can fail.

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: Not mine.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Oh, I'm sorry. You said you were married.

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: Yeah, happily.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: That's okay. Sex can wane in any marriage over time.

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: No, neither of us. Celibacy is a choice. This is our orientation. We're asexual.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You're making a mistake. If I had the power to veto him, given all the crap I've put up with over the years, don't know if I could use it objectively.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I do, I can, I have.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Might be easier if you'd stay out of the room.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I thought it'd be different. This week. Supposed to talk to his P.O. about getting his ankle monitor off early.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You're saying he should defer to you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, I'm just saying what he's doing doesn't seem rational, which makes me think it's rational in a way I'm not privy to. He always has a plan.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And he's always self-destructive. He may just be shooting himself in the ankle.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I know it feels strange. Dr. Chase is just looking in your throat. We're in the hospital. You're fine.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: He coached youth soccer. Took a team that was 0-6 all the way to the state finals at Long Branch. Hey, thanks for doing this in here. Switching rooms can be very disorienting.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: You take very good care of him.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I love him. Sickness and health, right?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Upper esophagus is clear. Moving on to the G.E. junction.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Hi.

utterance.speaker: Joseph
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: I'm sorry. Family members only during procedures.

utterance.speaker: Joseph
utterance.content: Uh, I'll— I'll be outside.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Oh, no. Please, um, it's okay. Joseph helps me with my husband sometimes. He's a good friend.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Which means not family.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Surprised you didn't go into the diplomatic corps.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Oh, you think they're…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No, if they're having sex, it's probably with their genitals. Mallory-Weiss tear. Vomiting must have torn the lining.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You know that close to 1% of the population identifies as asexual?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We really gotta get you laid. If I have to plough that furrow myself, so be it.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I have a patient who's asexual.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Is she a giant pool of algae?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It's a valid sexual orientation. According to this article, at least.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, I think I read that too. Is that fugliness weekly?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: She's perfectly fine-looking. Happily married for ten years.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: To a guy who loves penis enough for the both of them.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He's asexual too. Ran a complete physical on her. Nothing wrong except a common bladder infection.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: 100 bucks says I can find a medical reason why she doesn't want to have sex.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're out of your mind if you think I'm letting you anywhere near my patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine. I won't go near her. Just give me her file and any blood samples you have left over.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No contact, whatsoever. You talk to her, the bet is void.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No contact. Plays to my strengths anyway.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Right now's not a good time, House.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not for the Dean of Medicine. But it's a perfect time if you're a member of my team. Which one are you?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What did the endoscopy show?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No signs of ulcers or blockages.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: But you found a tear just below the esophagus. Explains the bleeding.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Doesn't explain why he vomited so hard he ripped his insides.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: His liver enzymes are slightly elevated. Gallstones could've—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: no complaints of pain.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Steatohepatitis would make his AST and ATL levels rise.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you calling his liver fat? Start the patient on statins, and do a biopsy to confirm. And knock him out. I've heard he's a wiggler.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's no need to put him under. We can confirm fatty liver with an ultrasound. Just making an observation.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well done. Now, as a member of my team, you can make the equally-useful observations that the sky is blue, I'm wearing pants, and I'm ignoring your first observation.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Of course.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wait.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And there it is.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You're trying to screw with my confidence.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, if I wanted to do that, I'd tell you how much the nurses hate you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You're trying to get me to define myself as a subordinate to keep me from ever intervening, even if it's fully in the scope of my duties. Like now. This isn't about diagnostics, it's about what's safe for the patient. Do the ultrasound.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ultrasound it is. And the nurses love you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You don't think I knew House was gonna tell you to ignore me and not do the ultrasound?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: This is an ultrasound machine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Which you're gonna use to do an ultrasound-guided biopsy. Probably got a kit stashed here…

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: "Cuddy dark will waste his afternoon chasing conspiracy theories."

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You're letting him get inside your head. He could do a lot of damage in there.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Dr. Chase. He started vomiting again.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: This is why we stopped the antiemetics. We needed to see if it was still a symptom.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Okay. Here, you want this?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: It's okay, Andres. You're in the hospital. Here.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: 10 milligrams of Diazepam!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Already on it.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I'm fine. I'm fine. I'm all right.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Blood in his urine.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Resume the antiemetics and increase the sedation. He really went after her.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Maybe he found out about her "good friend."

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It was just paranoid rage, typical of Alzheimer's. We don't even know if they were sleeping together.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: A few hours ago you were sure.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And that's significant why?

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Sorry. Only the bleeding's medically relevant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I wasn't being rhetorical. If they are sleeping together, why do we disapprove?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You're pro-infidelity?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's not married. If marriage is feeding and cleaning someone, limiting conversations, to repeating a few simple commands, then I was married to my pet rat. And a lot of people owe me wedding gifts. And we're walking, we're walking.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: I don't care how sick your spouse gets, you don't jump ship.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Alzheimer's is different. She can't share her problems with him, or plan for the future. The man she married no longer exists.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Yes, he does. He's in there. This is why you get married.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Said the divorced woman to the divorced man.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: I didn't jump ship. My husband sank it when he cheated on me. Commitment's not conditional.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She is there for him in the only way that matters now. She gave up her life to take care of him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which proves she's an idiot. If she had any sense, she'd have stuck him in a facility and jumped on that strange— Dr. Foreman! We were just looking for you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I was right about the antiemetics. If you kept him on them like I said, he wouldn't have gotten agitated and punched his wife.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, we're back to my supposed diabolical plan to shake your confidence. Let's see if this helps. If you're speaking as a team member, then I'd say you're a moron. Because taking him off the antiemetics gave us crucial diagnostic information. If you're speaking as Dean of Medicine, then I'd say you're a moron. 'Cause your micromanaging kept us from doing a biopsy. If we had, the patient would have been anesthetized hours ago, thus unable to go all Chris Brown on her ass.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Unless one of your index cards actually predicted the guy was gonna punch his wife, everything you're saying is post hoc rationalization.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Park, would you please reach under that chair? [House sits down on his chair. Park is sitting on the other side of his desk. She reaches under the chair House pointed at and finds an index card.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: "The patient will punch his wife."

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You clearly wrote that after the fact.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Adams, would you please reach into my pants?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: "Dr. Blackenshmurtz will accuse me of writing about the punch after the fact." Now, look. Here's a photograph of me holding a newspaper. Dated last Tuesday. Now, how could I have gotten my hands on that?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You done? Rhabdomyolysis fits the vomiting, pigmenturia, and renal failure.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: No muscle symptoms, and urine had no myoglobin. TTP fits, though.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Start him on plasmapheresis. Unless… unless I need to say, "mother, may I?" And mother is an abbreviation.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Fresh plasma will replace the damaged red blood cells that are clogging his kidneys.

utterance.speaker: Joseph
utterance.content: That sounds hopeful.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I've never been hit in the eye before. I feel kinda badass. I think maybe you should go. I'm fine. Okay?

utterance.speaker: Joseph
utterance.content: I’ll see you tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Okay. We're not having an affair.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It's none of my business.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I mean, not— not really. 'Cause nothing's happened. We've talked about it a lot, and… it's just really hard doing this by myself.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: When's the last time you had a full night's sleep?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You're not going to get any rest here. People who are sick are not the only ones who need to be taken care of.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Why doesn't Chase have to be here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think he knows anything about women who don't want to have sex?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Hormone levels are normal. This woman seems perfectly healthy. What does it matter if she says she's asexual?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's the fundamental drive of our species. Sex is healthy. Orgasms oxygenate the brain, lighting up over 30 different areas and making us forget how boring Susie Cooper is. That last one may not be universal.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: How about damage to her spinal cord blocking the signals from her genitals?

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Sex drive is in the brain. I suppose it could be psychological intimacy issues caused by childhood abuse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She's been sharing a toilet with the same guy for the last ten years.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: It's not the same. Sex releases oxytocin. It's the neurochemical basis for bonding.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And that's why men always marry their right hands.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: It's different for girls.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: No it's not. I've tapped over 30 guys and never wanted to see most of them again. I live next to a Jewish frat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We are veering wildly off track. Please continue.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: This woman's life is probably better off without sex. Eliminates most of her insecurity, she's immune to most advertising and can have honest relationships with men.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: We've run every test and ruled out all the options. You're gonna have to accept she just doesn't want sex.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lots of people don't have sex. The only people who don't want it are either sick, dead, or lying.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: So maybe she's lying. You think she's had a boyfriend on the side?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: For ten years? Sticking around the whole time? Doesn't make sense. What does…

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Everybody lies.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Followed your advice and took the night off.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Seems to have done you some good.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Mm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Where's my husband?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He's not in the hospital.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: So he just walked out?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: All of the shift nurses had their hands full with a double code.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Perfectly reasonable explanation. Same thing happened to me. Couldn't find my keys for days.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The police have been notified. I have staff searching.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I'm sorry.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: He has Alzheimer's! It's freezing outside, and he's sick! I mean, you don't even know what it is yet, do you?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The plasmapheresis hasn't had time to work, but TTP is our most likely—

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Okay, I'm just— I have to go look for him.

utterance.speaker: Joseph
utterance.content: Hey, don't be an ass. Can't you see she's upset?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, she's guilty. 'Cause instead of being at her husband's side, she was under you.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Okay, that's— y—

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah, yeah… He already said I was an ass. Personally, I applaud your decision to step down off your cross and get on with your life, but your misplaced guilt is shutting down your brain. We need you to sit, focus, and answer our questions.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, at 6:00 a.m., the patient wakes up, and the first thing he sees…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: In moments of confusion, Alzheimer's patients regress to old routines.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what would your husband do on a Saturday morning?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Nothing. Be at home.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What about a year ago? Or five years? Ten?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I don't know, um, he… he trained for a marathon once. Soccer practice. We took a cooking class.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That soccer trophy you were telling me about.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's gone. Where was practice?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: It was close to here. On Chesterfield.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Okay, he comes, he thinks he's waiting for practice.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: He'd want to get out of the wind. What's somewhere he could see the kids arrive?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: On three. One, two, three.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Not dead until he's warm and dead.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Get him to the ICU. Start him on extracorporeal circulation.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: That'll raise his temperature too quickly, it'll cause acidosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We can deal with his metabolism crashing, we can't reverse brain damage if we go too slowly.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Either way, we don't get his temperature above 95, it's not going to matter.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Multiple warm lavage is safer.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Do what House says.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: He has no heartbeat, and he's not breathing. How can he not be dead?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The body slows down when it cools, but it doesn't fully stop. We're warming his blood outside of his body, then putting it back. It'll raise his temperature enough that his heart should naturally start. Then we can shock it back into rhythm.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: And if it doesn't start?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Then there's nothing we can do.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You think it's possible he knew what he was doing? Like some part of him gets what he's putting his wife through, so he tried to—

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Kill himself? It's what I'd do if I were him. At least I wish I would.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If you really l love them back, then… yes.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: That's really dark.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It's not naive.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: I just believe people are capable of more than you do, apparently. We've got brain activity.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Temp's at 93. His heart should start soon. My dad left me alone to care for my alcoholic mom and raise my baby sister. I was just a teenager. I spent half my time changing diapers and the other half cleaning up my mom's vomit.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: But it must've been important that you stayed for both of them.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Mom died after a few years. It was ugly and painful, and she went with me hating her. My sister ended up drinking half of her life away and hating me because I couldn't help. After mom, I had nothing left. So do I wish mom had used a gun instead of a bottle? Yes.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: I— I didn't know.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: That's why I told you.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Ventricular fibrillation. 300 milligrams amiodarone. Careful. Once we establish rhythm, any accidental movement could crash him back into V-fib. Clear.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We still have a long way to go. Cold can be protective to the brain, but there is a possibility of damage. We also need to confirm and treat whatever's making him sick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I just gotta do a standard battery of tests. Blood, urine, EEG…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Excuse me. I have to deal with someone who's having a panic attack.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I specifically said the bet was off if you contacted the patient.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Exactly. Never said anything about the patient's husband.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The deal was a medical reason why she doesn't have sex.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I admit I was stuck, until I realized the medical issue was not hers but his. She's lying to compensate. It's a tale as old as time. Boy meets girl, girl falls for boy, boy says, "I'm asexual." Girl says, "yeah, me too."

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Your twisted logic can't hide the fact that tricking a patient into being tested is completely unethical.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Come on. Don't you think she deserves to know why her husband won't bend her over the kitchen counter? You love all that caring crap.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You're not doing this out of the kindness of your heart. You're not even doing this out of medical curiosity.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I thought I made it clear I'm doing it for the cash.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Two people are happy, and your natural impulse is to destroy it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How do you know she's happy? Did she tell you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No, chirping birds flew out of her butt carrying a banner.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: All right, I admit that my natural impulse is to doubt peoples' claims to happiness, but yours is to be a sucker for them. You tell me which one's worse.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: He just opened his eyes a little while ago. His heartbeat's doing well, and his body temperature is stabilized.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: There he is.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: Is that Portuguese?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Yeah. Honey, I don't understand.

utterance.speaker: Andres
utterance.content: Me sinto quente.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: What's he saying?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I don't know. I tried to learn when we got married, but I just — it's okay. It's okay.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: His body temperature is rising. It's above normal.

utterance.speaker: Park
utterance.content: I don't know.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Vomiting, liver, kidneys, and now fever.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't want to tell you how to do your job, Dr. Foreman, since telling people how to do their job is your job, but when your less-than-competent administration of this hospital affects what's written on my whiteboard…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Get to the point.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The word "fever." Could come from the patient's illness, or it could come from the fact that you allowed him to saunter out of your hospital and take a nap in the snow.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Couldn't have caught a virus while he was outside. Fever came on too fast.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The hypothermia could've caused cell necrosis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: TTP was the diagnosis when he walked out. Fever's a little high, but it still fits. We should continue plasmapheresis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We're missing symptoms. We should add language loss and aggression.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Should we also add forgetfulness? He's got Alzheimer's.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We've just been assuming.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because the patient's wife said he exhibited both for a year.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He's never hit her before or lost all his English. We have to consider any change since he's been admitted as relevant.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Have to? Do I need to pull out another card?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Disseminated viral infection with encephalitis. Patient complained of a sore throat a few weeks ago.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Start him on Interferon.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Encephalitis makes his brain swell, which causes symptoms that are hard to distinguish from his Alzheimer's. With the Interferon his English should come back, and the aggression should subside.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: But you're not sure.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Unfortunately, no.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: And you're not sure if he has brain damage from being frozen. So best-case scenario, I've just had a glimpse into his future? I can't take care of him anymore.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Chances are his mental state will improve. You could get more time with him.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: We married six months after I met him. A year after that, he started forgetting things. I've known my husband longer with his Alzheimer's than without. I've watched more of him disappear than I ever got to know. I just can't do this anymore.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You lose. Blood work shows high levels of prolactin. Add that to some peripheral red-green confusion, puts my money — excuse me, your money — soon to be my money, on a tumor near his pituitary. Probably started growing in his early teens.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Lowering his libido and causing erectile dysfunction.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: A year on dopamine agonists, and he'll be a sex-crazed creep just like the rest of us, completely fascinated by Susie Cooper. I'd prefer to be paid in a single $100 bill. Always wanted to use one to light a cigar.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Hooray for us. We disproved his asexuality. We also probably ruined his life.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He'll thank us. Then he'll doze off, and then in a couple hours, he'll thank us again.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It could destroy his identity. It's like a gay person being told they're really straight.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So don't tell him.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, why bother telling a guy he has a tumor growing in his head? He'll notice it eventually, when it starts leaking out his ears.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It's a slow-growing tumor. He'll probably die of boredom long before that.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You knew the second you told me about this case that I'd get involved. You wanted me to meddle. Because no matter how much you wanted to believe in this chaste romance, you didn't buy it either.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where's that petition House's P.O. sent over about getting his ankle monitor off?

utterance.speaker: Regina
utterance.content: On your desk.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You played me. This whole thing was about your ankle monitor. You weren't trying to undermine my confidence; you were trying to inflate it. You manufactured conflict with me so eventually you could let me win. You knew it was encephalitis, but you waited for me to say it because then with my ego boosted, you thought I'd be in the mood to take off your monitor because I'd think I could control you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You're right. Take off my monitor. See, the beauty of the plan is that if it works, you think you can control me. If it fails, then you will actually have proven that you can control me. It's pretty genius. These are your training wheels. If you think you're up to this job, it's time to lose them. Second half of my plan might need work.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: V-fib. Two rounds of 360 without establishing a rhythm.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: Wait, Dr. Foreman!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I sure hope this Alzheimer's drug trial is worth a lot to this hospital, 'cause we're wasting a crap-load of time and manpower just to let this guy watch his mind shrivel and keep his wife miserable.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Heart attack while he was on Interferon rules out encephalitis, but I still think I'm right about the neural symptoms. It's probably aseptic meningitis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Would have seen meningial signs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Given his abnormal mental status, not necessarily.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dr. Foreman, would you please reach under your chair?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There's just wet gum under here. Where's the card?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What card?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I'm happy to leave if you have a better theory than aseptic meningitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Toxins. This guy went on walkabout. Chances are he's done it before.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wife keeps the doors on the house locked.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Plenty of nasty stuff to get into during the middle of the night.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We asked about toxins on the history. The wife said she was sure to clear the house for her husband's safety.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm sure she succeeded. She's a PhD in toxicology, right? She's an ex-florist. Search the home for toxic plants, methyl bromide, any medications.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Stop. You're not infallible. You were wrong about encephalitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just before you were.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Run CSF tests. Find out what's causing the meningitis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You said you weren't gonna overrule me diagnostically.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And you said I wouldn't be able to help it. Apparently, you were right about that one.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine. I'll look for toxins myself.

utterance.speaker: Adams
utterance.content: You can't go to their house without Foreman's permission.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don't need it. I'll talk to the toxicology PhD upstairs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What about gifts from South America? Anyone send any fruits or vegetables?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: I don't think so, no.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I'm gonna need your boyfriend to collect samples of plants in and around your house. Toxins are the most…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He's— he's repeating, "blue shack." You know what that is? Is it somewhere where pesticides may be kept?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: It's where we had our first date.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you have a cleaning lady who might bring her own supplies?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: What's he saying?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If it's not relevant to the case, I don't care. And neither should you.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Please. This might be the last time I ever know what he's thinking.

utterance.speaker: Andres
utterance.content: La esta ela.

utterance.speaker: House and Natalie
utterance.content: There she is.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: He's still in there.

utterance.speaker: Andres
utterance.content: Quem e ela?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He asked who you were. Don't get your hopes up. Have your boyfriend give me those samples.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: How'd you even know to look for a tumor?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well, Dr. House noticed hormone levels in your blood, and consulted me as an oncologist.

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: Who cares how they found it, okay? They found it. Are there any side effects to the treatment?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Some nausea, dizziness, and as the tumor shrinks, there will be behavioral changes.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Like what?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Well… the tumor interferes with certain natural systems. Um… It lowers libido and causes erectile dysfunction.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Eh… Y-you mean the treatment will, um… m-make me want to have sex? Wh-what if I don't want the treatment?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I would strongly advise…

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: You have a brain tumor, okay? You have to have the treatment.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: Okay, look, I know who I am, okay? And I'm not one of them.

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: Hey, look, we'll adjust. Okay? We can go through this together.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: You mean have sex? I can't make you do that.

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: Maybe it won't be so bad.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: It'll be terrible.

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: It's actually pretty fun. From what I remember.

utterance.speaker: Man
utterance.content: But you said that…

utterance.speaker: Kayla
utterance.content: I know. I know. I wanted to spend my life with you. And I knew that meant making certain sacrifices. But a girl has needs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: With respect, Mr. Laffont, that's only because we temporarily shut down our Diagnostics Department. It's up and running again.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No, no, I just… Those flowers are from last week. They should be dead by now.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It's Reye's syndrome. Patient had a sore throat a few weeks ago before he was admitted.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Reye's in adults is a reach.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Not if he took aspirin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Aspirin in adults is a reach. Especially in a house with locked medicine cabinets.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wasn't in the medicine cabinet. Wife used to run a floral company. Still does a few orders from home. She uses crushed aspirin in the water to make the flowers last longer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So the husband has a sore throat, takes an aspirin without her knowing, realizes he's got a sore throat, takes an aspirin, realizes he's got a sore throat… Stop me whenever you like. Have Chase start him on steroids.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Already did.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then why're you telling me?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: 'Cause I wanted you to hear it from me.

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: Here I am.

utterance.speaker: Andres
utterance.content: Your eye. What happened?

utterance.speaker: Natalie
utterance.content: It's nothing I can't handle.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: MRI confirmed macroprolactinoma. He's doing the treatment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And the wife?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Come on. You saved a man's life. Course-corrected two peoples' wildly screwed-up world views. It's not bad for a day's work.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I think they were happy. Even if it was based on lies.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: We can't smoke in here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We also can't summon people into the clinic based on a lie motivated by a petty bet. And yet it happens. It's an imperfect world.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Disgustingly satisfying.

utterance.speaker: Uniformed man
utterance.content: Is one of you Dr. House?

utterance.speaker: Uniformed man
utterance.content: I got an order here to deactivate and remove his ankle monitor.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Hi, sis.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I know. I thought of you on mom's birthday.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah, yeah. Fine. I just…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: wanted to see how you were.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Now get out. I have work to do.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Whoops.
